Common Words 1.flashcard-text: noun: somebody who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Lady Gaga, in challenging what it means to be clothed, is an iconoclast for wearing a  meat dress  to a prominent awards show.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: complicated, and difficult to comprehend
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The physics lecture became so involved that the undergraduate’s eyes glazed over.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: restless
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The crowd grew restive as the comedian’s opening jokes fell flat.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to reveal or make known something, usually unintentionally
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: With the gold medal at stake, the gymnast awaited his turn, his quivering lip betraying his intense emotions.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: noun: a long pompous speech; a tiradeverb: to deliver a long pompous speech or tirade
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Dinner at Billy's was more a punishment than a reward, since anyone who sat at the dinner table would have to listen to Billy's father's interminable harangues against the government. Tired of his parents haranguing him about his laziness and lack of initiative, Tyler finally moved out of home at the age of thirty-five.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: to be in proportion or corresponding in degree or amount
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The convicted felon’s life sentence was commensurate with the heinousness of his crime.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: narrowly restricted in scope or outlook
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Jasmine was sad to admit it, but her fledgling relationship with Jacob did not work out because his culinary tastes were simply too parochial;  After all,  she quipped on her blog,  he considered Chef Boyardee ethnic food.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to weaken (usually paired with an abstract term)
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The student undermined the teacher’s authority by questioning the teacher’s judgment on numerous occasions.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: easily persuaded
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Even though she did not like the outdoors, Shirley was generally amenable and so her brother was able to persuade her to go camping.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to object or show reluctance
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Wallace disliked the cold, so he demurred when his friends suggested they go skiing in the Alps.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to speak in an evasive way
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The cynic quipped, “There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to prevaricate”.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: still in existence (usually refers to documents).
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Despite many bookstores closing, experts predict that some form of book dealing will still be extant generations from now.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to suggest something subtly
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: At first Manfred’s teachers intimated to his parents that he was not suited to skip a grade; when his parents protested, teachers explicitly told them that, notwithstanding the boy’s precocity, he was simply too immature to jump to the 6th grade.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to reprimand harshly
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Drill sergeants are known to castigate new recruits so mercilessly that the latter often break down during their first week in training.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to reproach; to scold
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Bob took a risk walking into the  Students Barbershop —in the end he had to upbraid the apparently drunk barber for giving him an uneven bowl cut.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: noun: a deviation from what is normal or expected
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Aberrations in climate have become the norm: rarely a week goes by without some meteorological phenomenon making headlines.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: noun: An online GRE prep product used by tens of thousands of students worldwide. Learn more at gre.magoosh.com.
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: After using Magoosh, Tom improved his GRE score by 8 points and was then admitted into UC Berkeley.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to assert
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The scientist maintained that the extinction of dinosaurs was most likely brought about by a drastic change in climate.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: exhibiting artistic skilladjective: clever in a cunning way
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Picasso is generally considered the most artful member of the Cubist movement.Bernie Madoff's artful Ponzi scheme stole billions of dollars from investors and is considered the largest financial fraud in U.S. history.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to give a false representation to; misrepresent
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The smile on her face belies the pain she must feel after the death of her husband.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: not normal
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: According to those who do not believe in climate change, the extreme weather over the last five years is simply anomalous—daily temperatures should return to their old averages, they believe.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: confusing or ambiguous
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The findings of the study were equivocal—the two researchers had different opinions on what the results signified.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to respect deeply
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The professor, despite his sleep-inducing lectures, was venerated amongst his colleagues, publishing more papers yearly than all of his peers combined.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to express strong disapproval
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: After being caught in bed with a mistress, the mayor was quickly censured by the city council.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: not spending much money (but spending wisely)
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: being disrespectful; improperly forward or bold
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Dexter, distraught over losing his pet dachshund, Madeline, found the police officer’s questions impertinent—after all, he thought, did she have to pry into such details as to what Madeline’s favorite snack was?

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to make less severe; to limit (a statement)
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Chris qualified his love for San Francisco, adding he didn't like the weather there as much as he liked the weather in Los Angeles.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: open to more than one interpretation
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The coach told his team, “Move towards that side of the field”; because he did not point, his directions were ambiguous, and the team had no idea to which side he was referring.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to reprimand harshly
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Though chastised for eating the snacks for the party, Lawrence shrugged off his mother’s harsh words, and continued to plow through jars of cookies and boxes of donuts.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: noun: making of a false statement meant to injure a person’s reputation
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: With the presidential primaries well under way, the air is thick with calumny, and the mud already waist-high.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: noun: the condition of being susceptible to bribes or corruption
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Even some of the most sacred sporting events are not immune to venality, as many of the officials have received substantial bribes to make biased calls.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: to be likely to socialize with others
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Often we think that great leaders are those who are gregarious, always in the middle of a large group of people; yet, as Mahatma Gandhi and many others have shown us, leaders can also be introverted.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to clear of accusation, blame, suspicion, or doubt with supporting arguments or proof
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Even seven Tour de France wins cannot vindicate Lance Armstrong in the eyes of the public--that the athlete used performance enhancing drugs invalidates all those wins.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: (of a person) prone to unexpected and unpredictable changes in mood
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The fact that Ella’s moods were as mercurial as the weather was problematic for her relationships—it didn’t help that she lived in Chicago.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: mixed or conflicting emotions about something
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Sam was ambivalent about studying for the exam because doing so ate up a lot of his time, yet he was able to improve his analytical skills.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: to be naïve and innocent
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Two-years in Manhattan had changed Jenna from an ingenuous girl from the suburbs to a jaded urbanite, unlikely to fall for any ruse, regardless of how elaborate.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: standing out in a negative way; shockingly bad
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The dictator’s abuse of human rights was so egregious that many world leaders demanded that he be tried in an international court for genocide.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: extremely frugal; miserly
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Katie is so parsimonious that she only buys a pair of socks if all of her other socks have holes in them.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: spending resources recklessly or wastefullynoun: someone who spends resources recklessly or wastefully
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The composer Wagner, while living on a limited salary, was so profligate as to line all the walls of his apartment with pure silk.   Most lottery winners go from being conservative, frugal types to outright profligates who blow millions on fast cars, lavish homes, and giant yachts.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: truthful
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: While we elect our leaders in the hope that every word they speak  will be veracious, history has shown that such a hope is naive.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: unbiased; neutral
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The potential juror knew the defendant, and therefore could not serve on the jury, which must consist only of disinterested members.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to excite or inspire (someone) to action
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: At mile 23 of his first marathon, Kyle had all but given up, until he noticed his friends and family holding a banner that read, “Go Kyle”; galvanized, he broke into a gallop, finishing the last three miles in less than 20 minutes.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: noun: a mixture of multiple things
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The band’s music was an amalgam of hip-hop, flamenco and jazz, blending the three styles with surprising results.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: harmless and doesn’t produce any ill effects
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Everyone found Nancy’s banter innocuous—except for Mike, who felt like she was intentionally picking on him.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: favorable, the opposite of sinister
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Despite an auspicious beginning, Mike’s road trip became a series of mishaps, and he was soon stranded and penniless, leaning against his wrecked automobile.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: rashly or wastefully extravagant
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: Successful professional athletes who do not fall prey to prodigality seem to be the exception—most live decadent lives.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: verb: to sap energy from
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: John preferred to avoid equatorial countries; the intense sun would always leave him enervated after he’d spent the day sightseeing.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: noun: bitterness and ill will
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: The acrimony between the president and vice-president sent a clear signal to voters: the health of the current administration was imperiled.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: (describes a person, speech, or style of writing) using very few words
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: While Martha always swooned over the hunky, laconic types in romantic comedies, her boyfriends inevitably were very talkative—and not very hunky.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: lacking
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: She did not think her vocabulary was wanting, yet there were so many words that inevitably she found a few she didn't know.

Common Words 1.flashcard-text: adjective: shapeless
Common Words 1.flashcard-example: His study plan for the GRE was at best amorphous; he would do questions from random pages in any one of seven test prep books.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: verb: avoid and stay away from deliberately; stay clear of
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Politicians are the masters of eschewing morals; academics are the masters of eschewing clarity.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: instructive (especially excessively)
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Tolstoy's The Death of Ivan Ilyich is a didactic novel, instructing the reader on how to live a good life.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: marked by a lack of interest
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Mr. Thompson was so talented at teaching math that even normally apathetic students took interest.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: verb: make worse
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Her sleeplessness exacerbated her cold--when she woke up the next day, her sinuses were completely blocked.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: noun: a strong liking
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Monte had a predilection for the fine things in life: Cuban cigars, 200 dollar bottles of wine, and trips to the French Riviera.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: verb: make unclearadjective: known by only a few
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: On the Smith's drive through the Grand Canyon, Mr. Smith's big head obscured much of Mrs. Robinson's view, so that she only saw momentary patches of red rock.Many of the biggest movie stars were once obscure actors who got only bit roles in long forgotten films.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: relevant and appropriate
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The professor wanted to tell the jury in detail about his new book, but the lawyer said it wasn't germane to the charges in the cases.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: noun: a state of guilt
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Since John had left his banana peel at the top of the stairwell, he accepted culpability for Martha's broken leg.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: verb: make less severe or harshverb: lessen the severity of an offense
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: I can only spend so much time mitigating your disagreements with your wife, and at certain point, you need to do it on your own.If it weren't for the mitigating circumstances, he would have certainly lost his job.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: occurring by happy chance; having no cause or apparent cause
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Missing my train turned out to be quite fortuitous since I ran into a childhood friend on the next train and we were able to reconnect after so many years.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: noun: the trait of being rude and impertinentnoun: feeling of deep and bitter anger and ill-will
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The speeding car had the gall to switch five lanes at once, run through a red light, and then cut off a police car before finally coming to a stop in front of a sea of flashing red lights.In an act of gall, Leah sent compromising photos of her ex-boyfriend to all his co-workers and professional contacts.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: verb: keep from happening or arising; make impossible
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The manager specified that all other gates be locked, to preclude the possibility of persons without tickets entering the arena undetected.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: noun: an act of deliberate betrayal; a breach of a trust
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Sure, he was the best salesman in the company; but Michael had abused the trust of the firm, sharing product secrets with a competitor, and for such perfidy he was terminated.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: without any attempt at concealment; completely obvious
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Among the tall trees and flower fields, the building seemed out of place with its conspicuous, cold concrete and angular steel exterior.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: characterized by good taste in manners and conduct
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Sally's parties are decorous affairs, and instead of the usual beer and music, there is tea and intellectual conversation.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: serving no useful purposeadjective: more than is needed, desired, or required
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: How can we hope to stay open if we don't eliminate all superfluous spending, like catered meetings and free acupuncture Tuesday?The third paragraph in your essay is superfluous and can be deleted.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: noun: one who professes great sensitivity to the beauty of art and nature
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: A true aesthete, Marty would spend hours at the Guggenheim Museum, staring at the same Picasso.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: expecting unquestioning obedience; characteristic of an absolute ruler
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The coach was dictatorial in his approach: no players could ever argue or question his approach.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: having or demonstrating ability to recognize or draw fine distinctions
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The lawyer had an incisive mind, able in a flash to dissect a hopelessly tangled issue and isolate the essential laws at play.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: concerned with the appreciation of beautynoun: a set of principles underlying and guiding the work of a particular artist or artistic movement.
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The director, not known for his aesthetic sensibilities, decided not to use costumes at all, and put on the play in everyday clothing.The artist operated according to a peculiar aesthetic, not considering any photograph to be worth publishing unless it contained a marine mammal.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: fixed firmly or securely
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: By the time we reach 60-years old, most of our habits are so entrenched that it is difficult for us to change.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: noun: a trite or obvious remark
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The professor argued that many statements regarded as wise in previous times, such as the Golden Rule, are now regarded as mere platitudes.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: characteristic of rural life; awkwardly simple and provincial
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The vacation cabin had no electricity and no indoor plumbing, but despite these inconveniences, Nigel adored its rustic charm.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: not serious in content or attitude or behavior
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Compared to Juliet's passionate concern for human rights, Jake's non-stop concern about football seems somewhat frivolous.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: verb: deny or contradict; speak against or oppose
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: I can't gainsay a single piece of evidence James has presented, but I still don't trust his conclusion.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: characterized by unusual lightness and delicacy
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The gossamer wings of a butterfly, which allow it to fly, are also a curse, so delicate that they are often damaged.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: relating to the pleasant aspects of the country
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The noble families of England once owned vast expanses of beautiful, bucolic land.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: noun: inactivity resulting from lethargy and lack of vigor or energy
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: After work, I was expecting my colleagues to be enthusiastic about the outing, but I found them in a state of complete torpor.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: verb: reach the highest or most decisive point
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Beethoven's musical genius culminated in the 9th Symphony, which many consider his greatest work.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: highly opinionated, not accepting that one's own beliefs may not be correct
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Bryan is dogmatic in his belief that the earth is flat, claiming that all pictures of a spherical earth are computer generated.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: habitually complaining
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The querulous old woman was beginning to wear down even the happier members of the staff with her ceaseless complaining.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: willing to be bold in social situations or to take risks
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: As all of the other campers cowered in their tents, Bill, armed only with a flashlight, audaciously tracked down the bear that had raided their food.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: verb: give rise to
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles were so severe that they engendered deep hatred and resentment in the German people.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: showing respect
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: If you ever have the chance to meet the president, stand up straight and be deferential.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: difficult to penetrate; incomprehensible to one of ordinary understanding or knowledge
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: I found Ulysses recondite and never finished the book, waiting instead to read it with someone else so we could penetrate its meaning together.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: verb: criticize severely or angrily
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Showing no patience, the manager utterly lambasted the sales team that lost the big account.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: disinclined to talk, not revealing one's thoughts
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: When asked about her father, Helen lost her outward enthusiasm and became rather reticent.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: improperly forward or bold
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: In an impudent move, the defendant spoke out of order to say terribly insulting things to the judge.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: noun: the quality of talking or writing easily and continuously
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The professor's volubility knows no bounds; he could talk through a hurricane and elaborate a point from one St. Patrick's Day to the next.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The professor used such banal expression that many students in the class either fell asleep from boredom or stayed awake to complete his sentences and humor friends.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: noun: an excessive supplyverb: supply with an excess of
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The Internet offers such a glut of news related stories that many find it difficult to know which story to read first.In the middle of economic crises, hiring managers find their inboxes glutted with resumes.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: marked by extreme care in treatment of details
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The Japanese noodle maker was meticulous in making his noodles and would never let another person take over the task.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: conspicuously and offensively loud; given to vehement outcry
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: In giving Marcia a particular vociferous response, Paul caused people at every other table in the restaurant to turn around and look at them angrily.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: impossible to stop or prevent
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The rise of the computer was an inexorable shift in technology and culture.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: noun: A place to find valuable information including study schedules and GRE tips.  Learn more at http://magoosh.com/gre
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Lena used the 1 month study schedule on the Magoosh blog to score well on the GRE.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: overly sentimental to the point that it is disgusting
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: The film was incredibly mawkish, introducing highly likeable characters only to have them succumb to a devastating illness by the end of the movie.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: noun: the power to foresee the future
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Baxter's warnings about investing in technology stocks seemed like an act of prescience after the whole market declined significantly.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: verb: to chuckle, laugh merrily, often in a breathy, muffled way
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Walking into the cafe, I could hear happy, chortling people and smell the rich aroma of roasted coffee beans.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: verb: acknowledge defeatverb: admit (to a wrongdoing)verb: give over; surrender or relinquish to the physical control of another
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: I concede. You win!After a long, stern lecture from her father, Olivia conceded to having broken the window.The Spanish were forced to concede much of the territory they had previously conquered.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: showing modest reserve; lacking self-confidence
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: As a young girl she was diffident and reserved, but now as an adult, she is confident and assertive.

Common Words 2.flashcard-text: adjective: mysterious or vague, usually intentionally
Common Words 2.flashcard-example: Since Sarah did not want her husband to guess the Christmas present she had bought him, she only answered cryptically when he would ask her questions about it.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: verb: make clearer and easier to understand
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Youtube is great place to learn just about anything--an expert elucidates finer points so that even a complete novice can learn.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: not original but drawing strongly on something already in existence, especially in reference to a creative product (e.g. music, writing, poetry etc.).
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Because the movies were utterly derivative of other popular movies, they did well at the box office.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: verb: to make someone who is angry less angry; placate
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: In the morning, Janine was unable to mollify Harry, if he happened to become angry, unless he'd had his cup of coffee.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: traveling from place to place to work
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Doctors used to be itinerant, traveling between patients' homes.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: verb: come from; be connected by a relationship of blood, for exampleverb: reason by deduction; establish by deduction
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Many words in the English language are derived from Latin, including the word derive. From the multiple set of footprints in the living room, the investigator derived an important clue: Sheila was not alone in the room at the time of the murder.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: comprised of a variety of styles
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Malala was known for her eclectic tastes in music, one moment dancing to disco the next air conducting along to Beethoven's 9th symphony.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: tending to betrayadjective: dangerously unstable and unpredictable
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Even though Jesse James was an outlaw, his killer, Robert Ford, is remembered more for his treacherous actions than for eliminating a criminal and murderer.The bridge built from twine and vine is treacherous to walk across, and so I think I will stay put right here.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: found in the ordinary course of events
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Phil gets so involved thinking about Aristotle's arguments that he totally forgets quotidian concerns, such as exercising and eating regularly.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: lasting a very short time
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: The lifespan of a mayfly is ephemeral, lasting from a few hours to a couple of days.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: noun: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Widespread apathy among voters led to a very small turnout on election day.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: verb: to pull off a plan or scheme, usually through skill or trickery
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Despite a low GPA, he contrived to get into college, going so far as to write his own glowing letters of recommendation.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: plausible but false
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: When listening to a politician speak, it is hard to distinguish the spurious claims from the authentic ones.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: marked by or showing hopelessness
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: After her third pet dog died, Marcia was simply forlorn: this time even the possibility of buying a new dog no longer held any joy.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: noun: an absurd presentation of something; a mockery
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: What I expected to be an intelligent, nuanced historical documentary turned out to be a poorly-produced travesty of the form.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: verb: cleverly find a way out of one's duties or obligations
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: One way of circumventing the GRE is to apply to a grad school that does not require GRE scores.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: verb: hinder or prevent (the efforts, plans, or desires) of
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: I thought I would finish writing the paper by lunchtime, but a number of urgent interruptions served to frustrate my plan.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: verb: place side by side for contrast
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: The appeal of her paintings comes from a classical style which is juxtaposed with modern themes.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: discontented as toward authority
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: After watching his superior take rations from the soldiers, he quickly became disaffected and rebelled.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: marked by extreme intensity of emotions or convictions
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: While the other employees responded to the bad news in a measured way, Andrew responded in a vehement manner, tipping over his desk and shouting at the top of his lungs.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: verb: choose not to consume or take part in (particularly something enjoyable)
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Considered a health nut, Jessica abstained from anything containing sugar--even chocolate.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: being essentially equal to something
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: In many situations, remaining silent is tantamount to admitting guilt, so speak to prove your innocence.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: full of high-spirited delight because of triumph or success
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: My hardwork paid off, and I was jubilant to receive a perfect score on the GRE.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: noble and generous in spirit, especially towards a rival or someone less powerful
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: He was a great sportsman: in defeat he was complimentary and in victory he was magnanimous.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: so small as to be meaningless; insignificant
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: The GRE tests cumulative knowledge, so if you cram the night before it is, at best, likely to only have a negligible impact on your score.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: not inclined towards physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: As the sun beat down and the temperature climbed higher, we spent a languid week lying around the house.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: characteristic of one eager to fight
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Tom said that he was arguing the matter purely for philosophical reasons, but his belligerent tone indicated an underlying anger about the issue.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: stubbornly resistant to authority or control
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Used to studious high school students, Martha was unprepared for the refractory Kindergarteners who neither sat still nor listened to a single word she said.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: not able to be changed
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Taxes are one of the immutable laws of the land, so there is no use arguing about paying them.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: characterized by or characteristic of exceptionally early development or maturity (especially in mental aptitude)
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Though only seven years old, she was a precocious chess prodigy, able to beat players twice her age.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: noun: distinctive and showy elegance
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Jim, with his typical panache, came to the wedding reception with a top hat and cane.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: verb: spread negative information about
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Todd was noble after the divorce, choosing to say only complimentary things about Barbara, but Barbara did not hesitate to vilify Todd.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: noun: A sample of lesson videos and practice questions to see if Magoosh is right for you.  Learn more at http://gre.magoosh.com
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Rachel tried the Magoosh free trial to determine if the premium Magoosh service was worth purchasing.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: excessively greedy
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Since avaricious desire is similar to gluttony or lust--sins of excess--it was listed as one of the seven deadly sins by the Catholic church.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: working in a subtle but destructive way
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Plaque is insidious: we cannot see it, but each day it eats away at our enamel, causing cavities and other dental problems.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: standing above others in quality or position
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Shakespeare is an eminent author in the English language, but I find his writing uninteresting and melodramatic.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: stubbornly unyielding
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Even the most tenacious advocates for gun ownership must admit some of the dangers that firearms present.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as unworthy
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: The haughty manager didn't believe that any of his subordinates could ever have an insight as brilliant as his own.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: being in the earliest stages of development; being or involving basic facts or principles
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: I would love to be able to present a fully polished proposal to the board, but right now, our plans for the product are still in the most rudimentary stages.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: noun: fanatical patriotism
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: North Korea maintains intense control over its population through a combination of jingoism and cult of personality.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: firm and dependable especially in loyalty
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: No longer a staunch supporter of the movement, Todd now will openly question whether its goals are worthwhile.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: free of deceit
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: At first I thought my niece was guileless, but I then found myself buying her ice cream every time we passed a shop.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: practicing self-denialnoun: one who practices great self-denial
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: His ascetic life is the main reason he inspired so many followers, especially since he gave up wealth and power to live in poverty.Historically, ascetics like Gandhi are often considered wise men partially because of their restraint.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: verb: make something bad better
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Three Cups of Tea  tells the story of western man who hopes to ameliorate poverty and the lack of education in Afghanistan.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: of a belief that is based on faulty reasoning
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: The widespread belief that Inuit have forty different words for  snow  has been considered fallacious, based on a single report by Anthropologist Franz Boas.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: verb: describe in detail
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: After a brief summary of proper swimming technique, the coach delineated the specifics of each stroke, spending 30 minutes alone on the backstroke.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: verb: take the place or move into the position of
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: For many, a cell phone has supplanted a traditional phone; in fact, most 20-somethings don't even have a traditional phone anymore.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: noun: a person who holds unorthodox opinions in any field (not merely religion)
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Though everybody at the gym told Mikey to do cardio before weights, Mikey was a heretic and always did the reverse.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: admitting of no doubt or misunderstanding; having only one meaning or interpretation and leading to only one conclusion
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: The President's first statement on the subject was vague and open to competing interpretations, so when he spoke to Congress about the same subject later, he was careful to make his position completely unequivocal.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: verb: be a sign or indication of; have as a meaning
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: Even if the text is not visible, the red octagon denotes  stop  to all motorists in America.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: verb: contain or includeverb: consider (an instance of something) as part of a general rule or principle
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: The rogue wave quickly subsumed the pier and boardwalk, destroying everything in its path.Don Quixote of La Mancha subsumes all other modern novels, demonstrating modern literary devices and predating even the idea of a postmodern, metanarrative.

Common Words 3.flashcard-text: adjective: lacking in harmony or compatibility or appropriateness
Common Words 3.flashcard-example: The vast economic inequality of modern society is incongruous with America's ideals.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: difficult to understand; incomprehensible
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Physics textbooks can seem so abstruse to the uninitiated that readers feel as though they are looking at hieroglyphics.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: easily irritated or annoyed
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Although the three year old was often described as mature for his age, he was petulant and whiny whenever his father forgot to remove the crust from his sandwiches.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: lacking foresight or imagination
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: The company ultimately went out of business because the myopic managers couldn't predict the changes in their industry.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: being of questionable authenticity
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: The web is notorious for sandwiching apocryphal stories between actual news.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: noun: the trait of seeming not to care
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: In an effort to fight indifference, the president of the college introduced a new, stricter grading system.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: characteristic of a limited perspective; not fashionable or sophisticated
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Maggie's enthusiasm about her high school teams seemed provincial to her college classmates, all of whom were following a nationally ranked college team.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: describing a statement that is not believable
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: The teacher found it implausible that the student was late to school because he had been kidnapped by outlaws on horseback.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: verb: grow and flourish
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: China's housing market is burgeoning, but some predict that the growth is merely a bubble and will burst much like the U.S. real estate bubble of 2008.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: guided by practical experience and observation rather than theory
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Rather than make a philosophical appeal to the Congressmen, the Speaker decided to take a far more pragmatic approach, making small side-deals that would add votes to his bill.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: verb: to cause confusion verb: mistake one thing for another
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Though Harry loved numbers, calculus confounded him.Americans often confound sweet potatoes with yams, and refer to both vegetables by the same name.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: verb: to adopt or support an idea or cause
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: As a college student, Charlie espoused Marxism, growing his beard out and railing against the evils of the free-market.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: dishonorable
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: In 1919, the World Series was rigged--an ignoble act which baseball took decades to recover from.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: constituting a separate entity or part
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: What was once known as Czechoslovakia has since split into two discrete, independent nations.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: noun: the trait of avoiding excesses
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Welles wasn't known for his temperance--he usually ate enough for two and drank enough for three.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: harsh in tone
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Most movie critics are acerbic towards summer blockbusters, often referring to them as garbage.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: marked by a narrow focus on or display of learning especially its trivial aspects
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Professor Thompson was regarded as an expert in his field, but his lectures were utterly pedantic, focused on rigorous details of the most trivial conventions in the field.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: markedly different from an accepted norm
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: When the financial director started screaming and throwing food at his co-workers, the police had to come in to deal with his aberrant behavior.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: verb: interpreted in a particular way
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: The author's inability to take a side on the issue was construed by both his opponents and supporters as a sign of weakness.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: inducing mental lethargy; sleep inducing
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Although the professor is brilliant, his bland monotone gives his lectures a soporific effect.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: verb: pronounce not guilty of criminal charges
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: The document clearly indicated that Nick was out of the state at the time of the crime, and so served to exonerate him of any charges.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: noun: someone who has been admitted to membership in a scholarly field
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Steven Pinker's credentials are unquestioned as a pundit; he has taught at MIT and Stanford, teaches at Harvard, and has published a number of influential books on cognition, language, and psychology.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: available when required or as promisedadjective: at ease in talking to others
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: The President announced that the senators were about to reach a compromise, and that he was eager to read the forthcoming details of the bill.As a husband, Larry was not forthcoming: if Jill didn't demand to know details, Larry would never share them with her.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: in abundant supply
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: In midsummer, there are copious popsicle stands at the beach; in the winter, there are none.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: noun: extreme generosity and giving
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Uncle Frank was known for his largess, so his nephew was sad when he did not receive a present for his birthday.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: marked by repeated turns and bends; not straightforward
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Because the logic behind McMahon's side of the debate was so tortuous, his audience came out either completely confused or, worse, feeling they'd been tricked.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: verb: to completely destroy
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: I tried eradicating the mosquitos in my apartment with a rolled up newspaper, but there were too many of them.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: noun: a behavioral attribute that is distinctive and peculiar to an individual
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Peggy's numerous idiosyncrasies include wearing mismatched shoes, laughing loudly to herself, and owning a pet aardvark.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: lacking significance through having been overused
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Cheryl rolled her eyes when she heard the lecturer's hackneyed advice to  be true to yourself.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: without any attempt at concealment; completely obvious
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Allen was often punished in school for blatantly disrespecting teachers.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: unwilling to change one's beliefs or course of action
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Despite many calls for mercy, the judge remained intransigent, citing strict legal precedence.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: noun: propriety in manners and conduct
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: You will obey the rules of decorum for this courtroom or spend the night in a jail cell,  said the judge to the prosecutor.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: verb: add details or explanation; clarify the meaning; state in depth
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: The CEO refused to expound on the decision to merge our department with another one, and so I quit.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: not clearly understood or expressed
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: The meaning of the professor's new research was opaque to most people, so no one asked any questions.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: lacking physical movement skills, especially with the hands
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Within a week of starting, the bumbling new waiter was unceremoniously fired.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: verb: prove to be false or incorrect
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: No one could refute his theories or propositions, and that is why he was esteemed by all his colleagues in the philosophy department.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: noun: a gathering of persons representative of some larger groupadjective: dependent on (usually used with upon)
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: A small contingent of those loyal to the king have gathered around the castle to defend it.Whether the former world champions can win again this year is contingent upon none of its star players getting injured.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: refusing to change one's mind
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Civil rights icon Rosa Parks will forever be remembered for adamantly refusing to give up her seat on a public bus--even after the bus driver insisted, she remained rooted in place.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: incapable of making less angry or hostile
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Win or lose, the coach was always implacable, never giving the athletes an easy practice or a break.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: defying tradition or convention
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Jackson Pollock was an iconoclastic artist, totally breaking with tradition by splashing paint on a blank canvas.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: verb: give extra weight to (a communication)
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: While the hiking instructor agreed that carrying a first aid kit could be a good idea under certain circumstances, he underscored the importance of carrying enough water.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: verb: praise or glorify
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: The teenagers exalted the rock star, covering their bedrooms with posters of him.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: verb: make (one thing) compatible with (another)
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Peggy was unable to reconcile her kind friend Jane with the cruel and merciless character Jane played on television.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: serving to warn; expressing reproof or reproach especially as a corrective
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: At the assembly, the high school vice-principal gave the students an admonitory speech, warning them of the many risks and dangers of prom night.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: without scruples or principles
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: In the courtroom, the lawyer was unscrupulous, using every manner of deceit and manipulation to secure a victory for himself.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: verb: gain favor with somebody by deliberate efforts
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Even though Tom didn't like his new boss, he decided to ingratiate himself to her in order to advance his career.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: requiring and demanding accuracy
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Though his childhood piano teacher was so exacting, Max is thankful now, as a professional pianist.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: noun: Determine how you'd do on an actual GRE exam by taking a practice exam.  Learn more at http://gre.magoosh.com
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Magoosh practice exams enabled Margarette to get a sense of what taking the GRE on test-day would be like.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: intended to attract notice and impress others; tawdry or vulgar
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Matt wanted to buy stone lions for front of the house, but Cynthia convinced him that such a display would be too ostentatious for a modest house in an unassuming neighborhood.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: impervious to correction by punishment
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Tom Sawyer seems like an incorrigible youth until Huck Finn enters the novel; even Sawyer can't match his fierce individual spirit.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: verb: charge falsely or with malicious intent; attack the good name and reputation of someone
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: Count Rumford denigrated the new theory of heat, demonstrating that it was wholly inadequate to explain the observations.

Common Words 4.flashcard-text: adjective: worthy of high praise
Common Words 4.flashcard-example: To say that Gandhi's actions were laudable is the greatest understatement; he overthrew an empire without violence.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: marked by great carelessness; dependent upon or characterized by chance
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Many golf courses are designed with great care, but the greens on the county golf course seem entirely haphazard.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: incapable of being retracted or revoked
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Once you enter your plea to the court, it is irrevocable so think carefully about what you will say.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: intellectually productive
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Schubert was the most prolific composer, producing hundreds of hours of music before he died at the age of 31.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: verb: to warn strongly, even to the point of reprimanding
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Before the concert began, security personnel admonished the crowd not to come up on stage during the performance.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: sharply contrasted in character or purpose
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: His deep emotional involvement with these ideas is, in fact, antithetical to the detachment Buddhism preaches.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: noun: aggressive boldness in social situations
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Mike was upset at the man who not only cut in front of him at the ticket counter but also had the audacity to cut in front of him at the bathroom line.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: noun: a person who tries to please someone in order to gain a personal advantage
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: The CEO was unaware of the damaging consequences of his choices, largely because he surrounded himself with sycophants who would never dare criticize him.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: noun: dominance over a certain area
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Until the Spanish Armada was defeated in 1587, Spain had hegemony over the seas, controlling waters stretching as far as the Americas.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: charming in a childlike or naive way
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: She was winsome by nature, and many people were drawn to this free and playful spirit.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: hostile (usually describes conditions or environments)
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Venus, with a surface temperature that would turn rubber to liquid, is inimical to any form of life.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: After the relatively small homerun totals in the  dead ball  era, Babe Ruth's homerun totals were truly prodigious: every year, he set a new all-time record.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: in opposition to an established system or institution.
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: The ruling political party has begun a campaign to shut down subversive websites that it deems as a threat to  national safety.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: full of trivial conversation
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Lynne was garrulous: once, she had a fifteen minute conversation with a stranger before she realized the woman didn't speak English.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: verb: reject as untrue or unfounded
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Many in the public believed the rumors of a UFO crash outside town, so the chief of police did everything he could to repudiate the rumors.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: feeling or showing profound respect or veneration
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: The professor could speak objectively about the other composers, but he always lectured about Brahms with a particularly reverent air, unable to offer a single criticism of his compositions.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: recurring in scattered and irregular or unpredictable instances
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: The signals were at first sporadic, but now we detect a clear, consistent pattern of electromagnetic radiation emanating from deep space.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: noun: Test your understanding of concepts from lesson videos.  Learn more at http://gre.magoosh.com
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Zach got  7/7 questions correct on a practice session using Magoosh practice questions.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: extremely hungry; devouring or craving food in great quantities
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: John didn't eat much at all during the week he had the flu, so now that he is regaining his health, it's not surprising that he has a ravenous appetite.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: not easily understood; unfathomable
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: His speech was so dense and confusing that many in the audience found it inscrutable.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: exceedingly harmful; working or spreading in a hidden and injurious way
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: The most successful viruses are pernicious: an infected person may feel perfectly healthy for several months while incubating and spreading the virus.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: moderated in effect
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: The wide-eyed optimism of her youth was now tempered after she had worked many years in the criminal justice system.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: verb: be undecided about something; waver between conflicting positions or courses of action
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Some students vacillate between schools when deciding which to attend, while others focus only on one school.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: characterized by extreme care and great effortadjective: having a sense of right and wrong; principled
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Because of his scrupulous nature, Mary put him in charge of numbering and cataloging the entire collection of rare stamps.Everyone trusted what he said and followed his example because he was scrupulous and honest.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: unrestrained by convention or propriety
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Their large  donations  to the local police department gave the drug cartel the brazen confidence to do their business out in the open.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: done with very great haste and without due deliberation
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Instead of calling his financial advisor, Harold acted precipitously, buying 4,000 shares of the latest  hot  stock, only to find out that the company had a history of inflating its year end numbers.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: noun: an amateur who engages in an activity without serious intentions and who pretends to have knowledge
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Fred has no formal medical training; while he likes to claim authority on medical issues, he is little more than a dilettante.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: verb: reject as untrue or unfounded
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Many in the public believed the rumors of a UFO crash outside town, so the chief of police did everything he could to repudiate the rumors.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: requiring secret or mysterious knowledge
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Most college fraternities are known for arcane rituals that those hoping to join the fraternity must learn.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: lacking social polish
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Sylvester says the most gauche things, such as telling a girl he liked that she was much prettier when she wore makeup.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: readily reacting to suggestions and influences; easily managed (controlled or taught or molded)
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Compared to middle school students, who have an untamed wildness about them, high school students are somewhat more tractable.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: fearless
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Captain Ahab was an intrepid captain whose reckless and fearless style ultimately led to his downfall.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: based on a random, groundless decision
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: One of the arbitrary decrees in place during the emperor's rule is that all citizens pay him weekly homage at his palace.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: noun: a citizen who is represented in a government by officials for whom he or she votesnoun: an abstract part of something
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: The mayor's constituents are no longer happy with her performance and plan to vote for another candidate in the upcoming election.The constituents of the metal alloy are nickel, copper, and tin.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: noun: an award or praise granted as a special honor
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Jean Paul-Sartre was not a fan of accolades, and as such, he refused to accept the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1964.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: verb: restrict or confine
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Their tour of South America was circumscribed so that they saw only popular destinations and avoided the dangerous parts of cities.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: rude and arrogant
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Lilian could not help herself from being insolent, commenting that the Queen's shoes were showing too much toe.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: noun: a large indefinite number
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: There are a myriad of internet sites hawking pills that claim to boost energy for hours on end.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: rising again as to new life and vigor
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: The team sank to fourth place in June, but is now resurgent and about to win the division.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: practicing self-denialadjective: unadorned in style or appearanceadjective: harsh in manner of temperament
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: His lifestyle of revelry and luxurious excess could hardly be called austere.Late Soviet architecture, although remaining largely austere, moved into experimental territory that employed previously unused shapes and structures.The principal of my elementary school was a cold, austere woman; I could never understand why she chose to work with children.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: verb: assign great social importance to
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Students in the U.S. learn to lionize Jefferson, Franklin, and Washington because they are the founding fathers of the nation.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: lacking imagination
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: While Nan was always engaged in philosophical speculation, her brother was occupied with far more pedestrian concerns: how to earn a salary and run a household.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: verb: exclude from a community or group
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Later in his life, Leo Tolstoy was ostracized from the Russian Orthodox Church for his writings that contradicted church doctrine.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: emotionally touching
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: After the Montagues and Capulets discover the dead bodies of Romeo and Juliet,  in the play's most poignant moment, the two griefstricken families agree to end their feud once and for all.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Many style guides recommend not using idioms in writing because these trite expressions are uninteresting and show a lack of imagination on the part of the writer.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: verb: give authority or permission tonoun: a legal penalty for a forbidden action
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: The authorities have sanctioned the use of the wilderness reserve for public use; many expect to see hikers and campers enjoying the park in the coming months.International sanctions have been placed on certain shipping lanes that were thought to be involved in human trafficking.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: very generous
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: Uncle Charley was known for his munificence, giving all seven of his nephews lavish Christmas presents each year.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: habitual
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: He is an inveterate smoker and has told his family and friends that there is no way he will ever quit.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: presenting favorable circumstances; likely to result in or show signs of success
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: The child's heartbeat is still weak, but I am seeing many propitious signs and I think that she may be healing.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: verb: cancel officially
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: The man's driver's license was rescinded after his tenth car accident, which meant he would never be allowed to legally drive again.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: attentive in an ingratiating or servile manner; attempting to win favor from influential people by flattery
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: The obsequious waiter did not give the couple a moment's peace all through the meal, constantly returning to their table to refill their water glasses and to tell them what a handsome pair they made.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: verb: try to stir up public opinion
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: After having his pay cut, Phil spread vicious rumors about his boss, hoping to foment a general feeling of discontent.

Common Words 5.flashcard-text: adjective: habitually reserved and uncommunicative
Common Words 5.flashcard-example: While the CEO enthusiastically shares his plans and agenda with all who will listen, the CFO is far more taciturn, rarely revealing his perspective.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: verb: call forth (emotions, feelings, and responses)
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Just smiling--even if you are depressed--can elicit feelings of pleasure and happiness.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: lasting a very short time
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: The unpredictable and transient nature of deja vu makes it a very difficult phenomenon to study properly.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: noun: a subtle difference in meaning or opinion or attitude
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Because of the nuances involved in this case, I hired an outside consultant to advise us and help.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: verb: cause to become widely known
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Before the effects of anesthesia were disseminated, patients had to experience the full pain of a surgery.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: marked by quiet and caution and secrecy; taking pains to avoid being observed
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: While at work, George and his boss Regina felt the need to be as furtive as possible about their romantic relationship.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: noun: an intense feeling of dislike or aversion
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Maria had an antipathy for tour groups, often bolting to the other side of the museum as soon as she saw a chaperone leading a group of wide-eyed tourists.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: full of or showing high-spirited merriment
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: The presidential candidate and her supporters were jovial once it was clear that she had won.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: noun: something that is not normal, standard, or expected
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: After finding an anomaly in the data, she knew that she would have to conduct her experiment again.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: noun: a trite or obvious remark
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Herbert regarded the minister's remark as a mere banality until Sharon pointed out profound implications to the seemingly obvious words.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: verb: criticize severely or angrily; censure
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: The police chief rebuked the two officers whose irresponsible decisions almost led to the deaths of seven innocent by-standers.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: verb: pacify by acceding to the demands of
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Neville Chamberlain, the British prime minister during WWII, tried to appease Hitler and in doing so sent a clear message: you can walk all over us.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: noun: the feeling of remorse or guilt that comes from doing something bad
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Those who show contrition during their prison terms--especially when under review by a parole board--often get shortened sentences.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: noun: a state of uncertainty about what should be done (usually following some important event)
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Ever since Elvira resigned as the head of marketing, everything about our sales strategy has been in a state of flux.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: (used of conduct or character) deserving or bringing disgrace or shame
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Since the politician preached ethics and morality, his texting of revealing photographs was ignominious, bringing shame on both himself and his party.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: noun: the tendency to be untruthful
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: I can forgive her for her mendacity but only because she is a child and is seeing what she can get away with.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: pathetically cowardly
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Though the man could have at least alerted the police, he crouched cravenly in the corner as the old woman was mugged.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: having or showing profound knowledge
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Before the Internet, the library was typically where you would find erudite readers.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: showing a brooding ill humor
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Herbert took board games too seriously, often appearing sullen after losing.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: not wise
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Hitler, like Napoleon, made the imprudent move of invading Russia in winter, suffering even more casualties than Napoleon had.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: verb: assume as fact
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Initially, Einstein posited a repulsive force to balance Gravity, but then rejected that idea as a blunder.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: enlightening or uplifting so as to encourage intellectual or moral improvement
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: I recently read an article in the Times about whether good literature is edifying or not; specifically, does reading more make a person more moral.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: demanding considerable mental effort and skill; testing powers of endurance
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: In order to deal with the arduous cross-country journey, truck drivers often survive on a string of caffeinated drinks, staying awake for up to 30 hours at a time.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: unaffected by strong emotion or prejudice
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: A good scientist should be dispassionate, focusing purely on what the evidence says, without personal attachment.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: expressing disapproval (usu. refers to a term)
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Most psychologists object to the pejorative term shrink, believing that they expand the human mind, not limit it.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: determined by chance or impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Nearly every month our capricious CEO had a new plan to turn the company around, and none of them worked because we never gave them the time they needed to succeed.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: verb: support and strengthen
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: The case for the suspect's innocence was bolstered considerably by the fact that neither fingerprints nor DNA were found at the scene.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: noun: a strong verbal or written attack on someone or something.
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: The professor launched into a polemic, claiming that Freudian theory was a pack of lies that absolutely destroyed European literary theory.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: unsure how to act or respond
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Shirley was totally nonplussed when the angry motorist cut her off and then stuck his finger out the window.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is right or proper in polite society
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Eating with elbows on the table is considered indecorous in refined circles.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: based on pretense; deceptively pleasingadjective: plausible but false
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Almost every image on TV is specious and not to be trusted.He made a career out of specious arguments and fictional lab results, but lost his job and reputation when his lies were exposed by an article in The New York Times.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: producing the intended result
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Since Maggie's cough syrup, which had expired five years back, was no longer efficacious, she coughed through the night.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: repetitive and boring; not spiritualadjective: relating to the ordinary world
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Nancy found doing dishes a thorougly mundane task, although Peter found a kind of Zen pleasure in the chore.Though we think of the pope as someone always dealing in holy matters, he is also concerned with mundane events, such as deciding when to set his alarm each morning.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: verb: interpret in the wrong way
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: The politician never trusted journalists because he thought that they would misconstrue his words and misrepresent his positions.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: noun: wealth as evidenced by sumptuous living
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Russian oligarchs are famous for their opulence, living in fancy homes and dining on expensive caviar.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: noun: compulsory force or threat
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: The witness said he signed the contract under duress and argued that the court should cancel the agreement.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: harmful to living things
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: The BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was deleterious to the fishing industry in the southern states.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: verb: to express criticism towards
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: At first, Sarah was going to yell at the boy, but she didn't want to reproach him for telling the truth about the situation.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: timid by nature or revealing fear and nervousness
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Since this was her first time debating on stage and before an audience, Di's voice was timorous and quiet for the first 10 minutes.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: demanding strict attention to rules and procedures
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Most of the students disliked the teacher because of his stringent homework policy, but many students would later thank him for demanding so much from them.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: noun: someone who exhibits great independence in thought and action
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Officer Kelly was a maverick, rarely following police protocols or adopting the conventions for speech common among his fellow officers.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: confined to and understandable by only an enlightened inner circle
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Map collecting is an esoteric hobby to most, but to geography geeks it is a highly enjoyable pastime.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: clumsy
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: As a child she was quite maladroit, but as an adult, she has become an adept dancer.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: troubled persistently especially with petty annoyances
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: With a team of new hires to train, Martha was constantly harried with little questions and could not focus on her projects.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: avoiding waste, efficient
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Journalists favor an economical style of writing, in which no unnecessary words are used and every sentence is as short as possible.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: verb: cause to be more favorably inclined; gain the good will of
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: I was able to placate the angry mob of students by promising to bring cookies on Monday.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: free from undue bias or preconceived opinions
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: The judge was not impartial since he had been bribed by the witness's family.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: verb: reduce the length of something
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: The soccer game was truncated when the monsoon rain began to fall.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: wasting time
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Lawyers use dilatory tactics so that it takes years before the case is actually decided.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: noun: After taking a practice exam, determine your score on the GRE 340-point scale.  Learn more at http://gre.magoosh.com
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Mike scored a 335 on a practice exam using the Magoosh score estimator.

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adverb: with a look of suspicion or disapproval
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: The old couple looked askance on the teenagers seated next to them, whispering to each other, They've got rings through their noses and purple hair!

Common Words 6.flashcard-text: adjective: overly concerned with details; fussy
Common Words 6.flashcard-example: Whitney is fastidious about her shoes, arranging them on a shelf in a specific order, each pair evenly spaced.
